verb.description: (of an event or circumstance) portend a good or bad outcome.
examples: the end of the cold war seemed to augur well
the return to the gold standard augured badly for industry

noun.description: (in ancient Rome) a religious official who observed natural signs, especially the behavior of birds, interpreting these as an indication of divine approval or disapproval of a proposed action.

origin: Late Middle English (as a noun): from Latin, diviner.
